title: 104_hr1501
content: The Act may be cited as the "Student Loan Privatization Act of 1995". The Congress finds that the Federal Direct Student Loan Program will increase employees at the Department of Education and hiring of Federal contract employees. Private sector involvement in student assistance leads to efficiency and innovation. Excessive regulation burdens the Federal Family Education Loan Program. The Federal Direct Student Loan Program faces challenges with inaccurate program costs and budget scoring under the Federal Credit Reform Act, leading to unrealistic savings projections. The Federal Direct Student Loan Program faces challenges with inaccurate program costs and budget scoring under the Federal Credit Reform Act, leading to unrealistic savings projections. Amendments to the Federal Credit Reform Act are proposed to improve accuracy. Amendment to Section 502(5)(B) of the Congressional Budget Act changes the calculation of the cost of a direct loan to include loan disbursements, repayments, interest payments, and other cash flows over the loan's estimated life. Management and Budget estimates that loan commitments for the coming fiscal year will exceed $5 billion, covering various expenses related to credit policy, oversight, loan activities, technical assistance, training, program promotion, payments, loan collection, and write-off. The basis point is multiplied by the total Federal debt obligations outstanding on the last day of the Federal fiscal year for each $50 billion outstanding in direct loans. SEC. 102. EFFECTIVE DATE. The amendment made by section 101 applies to fiscal years starting on or after October 1, 1995, and to statutory changes after the Act's enactment. TITLE II--PHASE-OUT OF THE FEDERAL DIRECT STUDENT LOAN PROGRAM SEC. 201. PHASE-OUT OF PROGRAM. Section 453 of the Higher Education Act of 1965 is amended to phase-out the Federal Direct Student Loan Program by modifying agreements with institutions of higher education. The Secretary will ensure an orderly transition for loans made in the academic year 1995-1996. The Federal Direct Student Loan Program will be phased out, with loans limited to 5% of new student loan volume for the academic year 1995-1996 and no loans made after the academic year 1996-1997. System modifications for the program will not be made, and regulations will govern the phase-out process. The Secretary will promulgate regulations for the phase-out of the Federal Direct Student Loan Program within 90 days of enactment. These regulations will not be subject to the Master Calendar provisions and will be implemented regardless of nonpublication. SEC. 202. DIRECT LOAN VOLUME LIMITS amended by striking paragraphs (2) and (3). SEC. 203. ADMINISTRATIVE EXPENSES amended to limit administrative costs and program expenditures. SEC. 204. REPEAL. SEC. 204. REPEAL. Part D of title IV of the Higher Education Act is repealed effective October 1, 1997. TITLE III--IMPROVEMENTS TO THE FEDERAL FAMILY EDUCATION LOAN PROGRAM. SEC. 301. RECOVERY OF GUARANTY AGENCY RESERVES. The last sentence of section 422(a)(2) of the Act is amended. SEC. 302. RESERVE FUNDS. Section 422(g) of the Act is amended regarding the disposition of funds returned to the Treasury. SEC. 303. TERMINATION OF FDSL CONSOLIDATION LOAN AUTHORITY. SEC. 303. TERMINATION OF FDSL CONSOLIDATION LOAN AUTHORITY. Section 428C(b) of the Act is amended by striking paragraph (5). Section 455 of the Act is amended by striking subsection (g). SEC. 304. CONSOLIDATION UNDER FFELP OF LOANS MADE PURSUANT TO PART D. Section 428C(a)(4)(B) of the Act is amended by inserting "part D or" before "part E". SEC. 305. ACCOUNTABILITY OF FUNDS FOR DIRECT LOAN ADMINISTRATIVE EXPENSES. SEC. 305. ACCOUNTABILITY OF FUNDS FOR DIRECT LOAN ADMINISTRATIVE EXPENSES. Funds under this section cannot be used for public relations or marketing activities. SEC. 306. SALE OF FDSL LOAN PORTFOLIOS. A new section is added for the sale of Federal Direct Student Loan portfolios. The Secretary will conduct auctions to sell loan portfolios without Federal guarantees or reinsurance. Loans will follow terms in the promissory note and not be subject to further regulations. After auctions, a report will be prepared. The Secretary will conduct auctions to sell loan portfolios without Federal guarantees or reinsurance, following terms in the promissory note. A report will be prepared, including the Secretary's opinion on the auction results reflecting Federal subsidy costs and estimates of reductions in administrative costs. Reports will be provided to the Congressional Budget Office and the Office of Management and Budget. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget will ensure that proceeds from auctions conducted by the Department of Education are returned to the United States Department of the Treasury after deducting expenses. SEC. 307. EFFECTIVE DATE. The amendments made by this title will be effective 30 days after the date of enactment.
